Declarative Memory.description: The long-term memory system responsible for storing facts and events.

Encoding.description: The process of transforming sensory information into a format suitable for storage in long-term memory.

Retrieval.description: The process of accessing and bringing stored information back into conscious awareness.

Attention.description: The cognitive process of selectively concentrating on one aspect of the environment while ignoring others.

Consolidation.description: The process by which newly encoded memories are stabilized and integrated into long-term memory networks.

Recall.description: The spontaneous retrieval of information from memory without any external cues.

Recognition.description: The process of identifying previously encountered information as familiar.

Selective Attention.description: The ability to focus on a specific stimulus while ignoring distractions.

Divided Attention.description: The ability to attend to multiple stimuli or tasks simultaneously.

Sleep.description: A crucial role in memory consolidation, particularly for declarative memories.

Synaptic Plasticity.description: Changes in the strength of connections between neurons that underlie learning and memory.

Free Recall.description: Recalling information in any order without any prompts.

Cued Recall.description: Recalling information with the help of hints or cues.

Familiarity.description: A feeling of knowing something without being able to explicitly recall the details.

Recollection.description: The conscious retrieval of specific details about a past event.

Serial Position Effect.description: The tendency to remember the first and last items in a list better than the middle items.

Retrieval Cues.description: Stimuli that help trigger the retrieval of a memory.

Long-Term Potentiation.description: A persistent strengthening of synapses based on recent patterns of activity.

Long-Term Depression.description: A long-lasting decrease in the effectiveness of synapses.
